questions.text: A 77-year-old man is brought to the emergency department by his wife because of headache, nausea, and vomiting for 24 hours. His wife says that over the past 2 weeks, he has been more irritable and has had trouble remembering to do routine errands. Two weeks ago, he fell during a skiing accident but did not lose consciousness. He has coronary artery disease and hypertension. He has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 50 years. He has had 2 glasses of wine daily since his retirement 10 years ago. Current medications include atenolol, enalapril, furosemide, atorvastatin, and aspirin. He appears acutely ill. He is oriented to person but not to place or time. His temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 99/min, respirations are 16/min, and blood pressure is 160/90 mm Hg. During the examination, he is uncooperative and unable to answer questions. Deep tendon reflexes are 4+ on the left and 2+ on the right. Babinski sign is present on the left. There is mild weakness of the left iliopsoas and hamstring muscles. A CT scan of the head without contrast shows a high-density, 15-mm crescentic collection across the right hemispheric convexity. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in the management of this patient?

choices.text: Obtain an MRI of the head

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

An MRI of the head is more sensitive than a CT scan for the detection of intracranial hemorrhage. However, CT scan of the head is the most widely used imaging study for acute head trauma because of its speed, simplicity, relative affordability, and widespread availability. Since a CT scan has already confirmed this patient's diagnosis, further confirmation with an MRI is not needed at this time.

B) INCORRECT:

Recombinant tissue-type plasminogen activator is used in the treatment of ischemic stroke. This patient has a subdural hemorrhage confirmed by CT, which is an absolute contraindication for thrombolytic therapy because it increases the risk of further hemorrhage.

C) INCORRECT:

A lumbar puncture (LP) is used in the diagnosis of suspected subarachnoid hemorrhage after a negative CT. This patient's CT scan showed a crescentic hemorrhage, so LP would not be indicated. LP would also place the patient at risk for transtentorial herniation because of increased intracranial pressure, as indicated by his cognitive impairment and worsening neurologic status.

D) INCORRECT:

The patient has symptoms of cognitive impairment and neurological decompensation with a hematoma > 10 mm on noncontrast CT scan of the head. Observation would not be the most appropriate next step in management in this case. Observation would be appropriate if the patient were clinical stable with no signs of brain herniation or neurologic impairment.

E) CORRECT:

In closed head injuries, rapid deceleration can cause shearing of the bridging veins that drain from the surface of the brain to the dural sinuses, leading to SDH. In cases of mild trauma, SDH can develop slowly and only provoke noticeable symptoms after days to weeks. Both this patient's age and alcohol consumption contribute to brain atrophy and stretching of the bridging veins, making him particularly susceptible to SDH. Management involves CT scan of the head without contrast and urgent surgical evacuation if there is evidence of neurological deterioration, the SDH is ≥ 10 mm, or there is midline shift ≥ 5 mm on brain scan.
Image Description:

CT head (axial view)

A hyperdense, crescent-shaped lesion (green hatched overlay) is visible over the lateral aspect of the left hemisphere. There is also a diffuse, hypodense area in the left hemisphere (green overlay) due to white matter edema and midline shift to the right (green line).

These findings are characteristic of a left subdural hematoma.

F) INCORRECT:

Electroencephalography is not indicated for the diagnosis or management of subdural hematoma. Electroencephalogram (EEG) is the diagnostic study of choice for the evaluation of epileptic seizures. EEG would be indicated if the patient had presented with a seizure and the CT failed to identify a cause.
questions.hint: An older patient with a recent history of a fall and presenting with signs of increased intracranial pressure (headache, nausea, vomiting), altered mental status, and focal neurological signs raises concern for subacute subdural hematoma (SDH). The CT findings of a crescentic bleed confirm the diagnosis.

questions.text: A 68-year-old man is brought to the emergency department by his wife because of a 2-week history of progressive disorientation and a 1-day history of left-sided weakness and difficulty speaking. The wife reports that the patient had a minor fall 4 months ago, during which he may have hit his head. He has hypertension and hyperlipidemia. He drinks 3–4 bottles of beer daily. He is only oriented to person. Neurological examination shows moderate spastic weakness, decreased sensation, and increased deep tendon reflexes in the left upper and lower extremities. A CT scan of the head is shown. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's condition?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Damage to the lenticulostriate arteries is most often a consequence of hypertension (Charcot-Bouchard microaneurysm), cerebral amyloid angiopathy, or vasculitis. Patients typically present with severe headache, focal neurologic deficits, and loss of consciousness. The onset is acute and progresses rapidly. CT imaging would show a solitary hyperdense lesion, surrounded by hypodense edema within the cerebral parenchyma.
Image Description:

CT head (without contrast; axial plane) of a patient with a history of chronic hypertension

Hyperdense hemorrhage in the left basal ganglia is surrounded by hypodense perifocal edema (red overlay).

The location is typical for hemorrhage from the lenticulostriate arteries as a result of long-standing hypertension.

1: head of caudate nucleus; 2: putamen; 3 and green overlay: internal capsule; 4: thalamus
Arrowheads: calcified pineal gland; white circles: calcified choroid plexus

B) INCORRECT:

Injury to the middle meningeal artery can lead to an epidural hemorrhage. The typical presentation of this injury is head trauma followed by normal sensorium (lucid interval) before onset of symptoms of increased intracranial pressure. CT scan would show a characteristic lentiform hemorrhagic collection (hemorrhage limited by suture lines).
Image Description:

Click on the overlay icon below the taskbar on the left to toggle the overlay on and off.

CT head (brain window: axial and coronal planes; bone window: axial plane)

A biconvex epidural hematoma (green overlay) with mass effect is seen in the left frontal region, adjacent to which is a small frontotemporal subdural hematoma (red overlay). A calvarial fracture (arrowheads) involves the left temporal and parietal bones.

C) INCORRECT:

Saccular aneurysm rupture leads to subarachnoid hemorrhage, which characteristically causes severe, abrupt-onset headaches (thunderclap headaches) that may be associated with vomiting, neck pain, and decreased levels of consciousness. While this patient has decreased levels of consciousness, he does not have any of the other characteristic symptoms, nor does his CT scan show blood in the subarachnoid space, as would be expected.
Image Description:

CT head (without contrast; axial plane)

Regions of high attenuation (green overlay) in the interpeduncular cistern, Sylvian fissures, and left posterior fossa represent acute subarachnoid hemorrhage. The cerebellar tentorium (red overlay) should not be misinterpreted as blood.

D) INCORRECT:

Embolus to the middle cerebral artery would cause an ischemic stroke. Most commonly, embolism results in acute-onset neurological defects as opposed to the subacute progression of this patient's symptoms. CT scans can present with a hyperdense MCA sign but are usually unremarkable for up to 24 hours after an ischemic stroke. MRI is the preferred modality for imaging acute ischemic stroke.
Image Description:

Click on the overlay icon below the taskbar on the left to toggle the overlay on and off.

CT head (without contrast; axial plane)

The right cerebral hemisphere is hypodense (green overlay) in the distributions of the middle and anterior cerebral arteries. The presence of thromboembolic material has caused the right middle cerebral artery (MCA) to appear hyperdense (hyperdense-MCA sign; white arrowhead). Cerebral edema has resulted in effacement of the sulci and the loss of differentiation between the medulla and cortex. Accompanying mass effect has compressed the right lateral ventricle (red overlay) and caused slight contralateral shift of the midline (indicated by white arrow and dashed line).

E) CORRECT:

SDH is caused by a rupture of the bridging veins, which cross the subdural space. This patient's history of minor head trauma followed by an insidious onset of disorientation is consistent with chronic SDH. The main risk factor for the development of this condition is diffuse cerebral atrophy associated with aging and/or chronic alcohol use. The new-onset unilateral neurological symptoms (spastic paresis, hyperreflexia, decreased sensation) are likely due to rebleeding.

See “Overview of intracranial hemorrhage” table.
Image Description:

Rupture of a bridging vein results in hemorrhage into the subdural space between the dura and arachnoid mater. Bleeding into the subdural space results in a crescent-shaped hematoma (right) that can cross suture lines but not the midline.

F) INCORRECT:

Intraventricular vascular malformations are a common cause of intraventricular hemorrhage. Like other intracranial bleeding events, the characteristic presentation includes sudden onset of headache, vomiting, and altered level of consciousness. Seizures are common but focal neurological findings are not. CT imaging would show blood within the ventricular system.
questions.hint: The CT scan shows a crescent-shaped, concave hemorrhage that crosses suture lines but not the midline. This finding is characteristic of a subdural hematoma (SDH).

questions.text: A 76-year-old man is brought to the emergency department by his son because of a 2-day history of increasing confusion and headache. He has a history of hypertension, atrial fibrillation, and carotid artery stenosis. The patient has been prescribed lisinopril, atorvastatin, apixaban, and aspirin but does not always adhere to his medication regimen according to his son. He drinks 1–2 glasses of beer daily and has smoked one-half pack of cigarettes daily for 50 years. He lives alone in his apartment. He is somnolent and oriented only to person. Temperature is 36.8°C (98.2°F), pulse is 76/min, and blood pressure is 140/92 mm Hg. Cardiopulmonary examination is unremarkable. Muscle strength is 5/5 in the right upper and lower extremities, 3/5 in the left upper, and 4/5 in the left lower extremities. Results of screening laboratory studies, including complete blood count, coagulation, and glucose are within the reference ranges. A CT scan of the head is shown. Which of the following is most likely to have prevented this patient’s current condition?

choices.text: Removal of tripping hazards from the patient's home
Endovascular coiling of an intracranial aneurysm

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Adherence to lisinopril therapy decreases the risk of an intracerebral hemorrhage (ICH). Arterial hypertension is the single most important predisposing factor for ICH. ICH typically manifests with headache, confusion, and focal neurological deficits, all of which are seen here. However, a noncontrast CT scan of the head would show a solitary hyperdense lesion surrounded by hypodense edema. Moreover, symptoms typically progress over minutes to hours rather than days. Another measure would more likely have prevented this patient's acute SDH.
Image Description:

CT head (without contrast; axial plane) of a patient with a history of chronic hypertension

Hyperdense hemorrhage in the left basal ganglia is surrounded by hypodense perifocal edema (red overlay).

The location is typical for hemorrhage from the lenticulostriate arteries as a result of long-standing hypertension.

1: head of caudate nucleus; 2: putamen; 3 and green overlay: internal capsule; 4: thalamus
Arrowheads: calcified pineal gland; white circles: calcified choroid plexus

B) CORRECT:

The removal of tripping hazards from this patient's home is most likely to have prevented his acute SDH by reducing his fall risk. Blunt head trauma due to a fall can cause shearing of the bridging veins, leading to an SDH. This patient's alcohol consumption and advanced age increase his risk of fall-related injury. Antithrombotic therapy, hypertension, arteriosclerosis, and cerebral atrophy (due to advanced age) are additional factors that make him particularly susceptible to SDH. Symptoms of acute SDH typically develop within 3 days after the inciting event and include altered mental status (e.g., confusion), headache, and focal neurological signs (e.g., contralateral hemiparesis), as seen here.

Unlike acute SDH, chronic SDH has an insidious onset with symptoms manifesting ≥ 3 weeks after the event. Additionally, CT scan of the head would show a hypodense, not hyperdense, lesion.

C) INCORRECT:

Smoking is a risk factor for ischemic stroke and nontraumatic subarachnoid hemorrhage, but it is not an independent risk factor for SDH. Another measure would more likely have prevented this patient's acute SDH.

D) INCORRECT:

Carotid endarterectomy can be performed to prevent ischemic stroke in patients with carotid artery stenosis (CAS). Although ischemic stroke can also manifest with focal neurological signs (e.g., contralateral hemiparesis) and headache, symptoms develop more acutely than those seen here. A noncontrast CT scan in ischemic stroke typically shows hyperdense occluded vessels (e.g., middle cerebral artery) and/or hypodense parenchyma in the first 24 hours; or a hyperdense parenchymal lesion after 24 hours of symptom onset. An extraparenchymal, crescent-shaped hyperdense lesion that crosses cranial sutures would not be expected. Carotid endarterectomy would not have prevented this patient's acute SDH.
Image Description:

CT head (without contrast; axial plane)

The right middle cerebral artery (MCA; green overlay) is hyperdense compared to the regions of the left MCA (arrow) and tip of the basilar artery (red overlay).

The hyperdense MCA sign is a marker of middle cerebral artery thrombosis. This sign is visible before parenchymal changes of ischemia.

E) INCORRECT:

Endovascular coiling of an intracranial aneurysm can prevent an aneurysm rupture and subsequent subarachnoid hemorrhage (SAH). Patients with SAH may present with headache, confusion, and focal neurologic deficits, all of which are seen here. However, a CT scan of the head in SAH characteristically shows blood in the subarachnoid space, not a crescent-shaped lesion that crosses cranial sutures. Also, headache associated with SAH is typically rapid in onset (thunderclap headache) and accompanied by meningism. Another measure would more likely have prevented this patient's acute SDH.
Image Description:

CT head (without contrast; axial plane)

Regions of high attenuation (green overlay) in the interpeduncular cistern, Sylvian fissures, and left posterior fossa represent acute subarachnoid hemorrhage. The cerebellar tentorium (red overlay) should not be misinterpreted as blood.
questions.hint: The CT scan shows a hyperdense, crescent-shaped lesion on the lateral aspect of the right cerebral hemisphere. The lesion crosses cranial sutures and does not cross the midline. These findings are characteristic of an acute subdural hematoma (SDH).

questions.text:
A 75-year-old man presents with a persistent headache that began 3 nights ago, when he stood up from dinner and hit his head against an open cupboard door in his home. He describes the pain as throbbing but not radiating and rates the severity as 4/10. He reports no relieving or exacerbating factors and no loss of consciousness, dizziness, nausea, vomiting, vision changes, or focal weakness. His social history is significant for consumption of 2 to 3 beers on most evenings.
On physical examination, his vital signs are normal. Head examination shows a bruise over the right forehead but no lacerations or swelling. Neurologic examination is nonfocal with normal muscle tone, strength 5/5 in the upper and lower extremities, and deep-tendon reflexes 2+ bilaterally. The rest of the physical examination is unremarkable.
Head CT without contrast is obtained (figure).
Which one of the following conditions is most likely to have led to this patient’s presentation?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Subdural empyema is a collection of pus between the dura and the arachnoid membrane. It often occurs in childhood as a complication of sinusitis or otitis media. Affected patients present with systemic symptoms such as fever and chills in addition to headache, focal neurologic deficits, and possible seizures. Evaluation for subdural empyema should be done by imaging alone because a lumbar puncture can cause a herniation.

B) CORRECT:

This patient’s presentation and imaging findings are most consistent with acute subdural hematoma. This type of hematoma is most commonly found in the frontal and parietal areas of the skull and is usually associated with a head injury. Even minor head trauma can lead to acute subdural hematoma in those who are predisposed because of cerebral atrophy. Cerebral atrophy leads to an enlarged space between the dura and the brain, thereby tensing the bridging veins and making injury and hemorrhage more likely. Potential causes of cerebral atrophy include older age and alcohol use disorder.

Neurologic findings in patients with subdural hematoma can vary depending on the severity of the bleeding and possible mass effect. Treatment in most patients consists of nonoperative management with serial monitoring by neurologic examination and neuroimaging, but operative intervention may be needed in some cases.

Key learning point: Subdural hematoma is a collection of blood between the dura mater and the arachnoid mater.

C) INCORRECT:

Subarachnoid hemorrhage is a form of intracranial bleeding between the arachnoid membrane and the pia mater. Characteristic symptoms include a sudden, severe headache that radiates to the occiput; vomiting; fever; and diminished levels of consciousness, often associated with meningeal signs, such as neck stiffness. These symptoms can occur spontaneously in the setting of a ruptured aneurysm or traumatically, such as after a blow to the head that causes a skull fracture. CT or MRI of head are the imaging modalities of choice and will show hyperdense or hyperintense signal in the subarachnoid space.

D) INCORRECT:

Meningiomas are slow-growing tumors of the meninges. Many are detected incidentally on imaging, but they can also manifest with a variety of neurologic symptoms, including headache, depending on the location and size of the tumor. However, symptoms are usually gradual in onset, and imaging would typically show a well-defined, extra-axial mass.

E) INCORRECT:

Epidural hematoma is a collection of blood between the dura mater and the skull. It is often associated with loss of consciousness, but other symptoms may include headache, confusion, focal paralysis, nausea, and vomiting. It is frequently associated with trauma and injury to the middle meningeal artery (rather than the bridging veins, as seen in a subdural hematoma). A characteristic finding is a brief period of temporary improvement of initial symptoms followed by drastic deterioration. MRI or CT of the brain will show a convex lens-shaped expansion within the skull with sharp borders rather than the crescent-shaped expansion seen with subdural hematoma.

Click on the overlay icon below the taskbar on the left to toggle the overlay on and off.

CT head (without contrast; axial plane)

The right cerebral hemisphere is hypodense (green overlay) in the distributions of the middle and anterior cerebral arteries. The presence of thromboembolic material has caused the right middle cerebral artery (MCA) to appear hyperdense (hyperdense-MCA sign; white arrowhead). Cerebral edema has resulted in effacement of the sulci and the loss of differentiation between the medulla and cortex. Accompanying mass effect has compressed the right lateral ventricle (red overlay) and caused slight contralateral shift of the midline (indicated by white arrow and dashed line).

E) CORRECT:

SDH is caused by a rupture of the bridging veins, which cross the subdural space. This patient's history of minor head trauma followed by an insidious onset of disorientation is consistent with chronic SDH. The main risk factor for the development of this condition is diffuse cerebral atrophy associated with aging and/or chronic alcohol use. The new-onset unilateral neurological symptoms (spastic paresis, hyperreflexia, decreased sensation) are likely due to rebleeding.

See “Overview of intracranial hemorrhage” table.
Image Description:

Rupture of a bridging vein results in hemorrhage into the subdural space between the dura and arachnoid mater. Bleeding into the subdural space results in a crescent-shaped hematoma (right) that can cross suture lines but not the midline.
questions.hint: The CT scan shows a crescent-shaped, concave hemorrhage that crosses suture lines but not the midline. This finding is characteristic of a subdural hematoma (SDH).

questions.text:
An 80-year-old man is brought to the clinic by his daughter due to a two-week history of progressive confusion, slow gait, and occasional mild headache. He fell while getting out of bed about three weeks ago but did not report any subsequent problems. He has well-controlled hypertension and no significant medical history. He denies fever or chills but states his appetite has diminished over the past week. On examination, he is oriented only to person, with slowed responses, but has no focal motor or sensory deficits. Laboratory studies, including complete blood count and basic metabolic panel, are within normal limits.
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Vascular dementia typically presents with a stepwise cognitive decline following cerebrovascular events, often with focal deficits. The gradual onset of global cognitive changes and absence of focal deficits or stroke history do not support this diagnosis.

B) INCORRECT:

Normal pressure hydrocephalus presents with a triad of gait disturbance, dementia, and urinary incontinence, developing insidiously over months to years. The rapid two-week onset of symptoms and absence of urinary incontinence make this diagnosis unlikely.

C) CORRECT:

Chronic subdural hematoma often occurs in older adults due to cerebral atrophy, which increases the risk of bridging vein tears after minor trauma. A fall can lead to a slow venous bleed, accumulating over weeks and causing symptoms like confusion, gait disturbances, and headaches. Neuroimaging, such as a CT scan, typically shows a crescent-shaped hematoma that can cross suture lines. Recognizing subtle neurological changes in an elderly patient with recent minor trauma is crucial for diagnosing this condition.

Key learning point: Chronic subdural hematoma should be suspected in older adults with a history of falls and gradual onset of neurological symptoms, even in the absence of a known head injury or focal neurological deficits.

D) INCORRECT:

Alzheimer disease is characterized by gradual memory decline over months to years. The acute two-week onset of confusion, slowed gait, and headache following a fall is inconsistent with the chronic progression of Alzheimer disease.

questions.text: You are seeing a 68-year-old man who is brought to the emergency department by his wife due to a 2-week history of progressive disorientation and a 1-day history of left-sided weakness and difficulty speaking. His wife reports that he had a minor fall 4 months ago and may have struck his head. His medical history includes hypertension and hyperlipidemia. He consumes 3–4 bottles of beer daily. On assessment, he is oriented only to person. Neurological examination reveals moderate spastic weakness, decreased sensation, and increased deep tendon reflexes in the left upper and lower extremities. A CT scan of the head is provided. Which one of the following is the most likely cause of his condition?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

SDH is caused by a rupture of the bridging veins, which cross the subdural space. This patient's history of minor head trauma followed by an insidious onset of disorientation is consistent with chronic SDH. The main risk factor for the development of this condition is diffuse cerebral atrophy associated with aging and/or chronic alcohol use. The new-onset unilateral neurological symptoms (spastic paresis, hyperreflexia, decreased sensation) are likely due to rebleeding.

See “Overview of intracranial hemorrhage” table.

Key learning point: Chronic subdural hematoma typically results from tearing of bridging veins, often after minor head trauma, and presents with gradually progressive neurological symptoms, especially in elderly or chronically alcoholic individuals.
Image Description:

Rupture of a bridging vein results in hemorrhage into the subdural space between the dura and arachnoid mater. Bleeding into the subdural space results in a crescent-shaped hematoma (right) that can cross suture lines but not the midline.

B) INCORRECT:

Embolus to the middle cerebral artery would cause an ischemic stroke. Most commonly, embolism results in acute-onset neurological defects as opposed to the subacute progression of this patient's symptoms. CT scans can present with a hyperdense MCA sign but are usually unremarkable for up to 24 hours after an ischemic stroke. MRI is the preferred modality for imaging acute ischemic stroke.

C) INCORRECT:

Injury to the middle meningeal artery can lead to an epidural hemorrhage. The typical presentation of this injury is head trauma followed by normal sensorium (lucid interval) before onset of symptoms of increased intracranial pressure. CT scan would show a characteristic lentiform hemorrhagic collection (hemorrhage limited by suture lines).

D) INCORRECT:

Saccular aneurysm rupture leads to subarachnoid hemorrhage, which characteristically causes severe, abrupt-onset headaches (thunderclap headaches) that may be associated with vomiting, neck pain, and decreased levels of consciousness. While this patient has decreased levels of consciousness, he does not have any of the other characteristic symptoms, nor does his CT scan show blood in the subarachnoid space, as would be expected.

E) INCORRECT:

Damage to the lenticulostriate arteries is most often a consequence of hypertension (Charcot-Bouchard microaneurysm), cerebral amyloid angiopathy, or vasculitis. Patients typically present with severe headache, focal neurologic deficits, and loss of consciousness. The onset is acute and progresses rapidly. CT imaging would show a solitary hyperdense lesion, surrounded by hypodense edema within the cerebral parenchyma.
questions.hint: The CT scan shows a crescent-shaped, concave hemorrhage that crosses suture lines but not the midline. This finding is characteristic of a subdural hematoma (SDH).

questions.text: You are seeing a 2-month-old boy in the emergency department. His mother reports an 8-hour history of difficulty feeding and decreased arousability, which began after he rolled over and fell from the bed. Vital signs are normal. On examination, there are regions of purple discoloration in the T4–T10 dermatomes bilaterally and tense fontanelles. Fundoscopy reveals bilateral retinal hemorrhages. Which one of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Bacterial meningitis is typically accompanied by altered mental status (AMS), which, in infants, can manifest subtly with symptoms ranging from irritability to lethargy. Although this patient's decreased arousability indicates acute AMS, he does not have fever or signs of meningism. This patient's presentation should raise concern for nonaccidental trauma.

B) INCORRECT:

Common manifestations of a basilar skull fracture include periorbital ecchymosis with CSF rhinorrhea, CSF otorrhea, mastoid ecchymosis, and otorrhagia, which are not seen in this patient. Therefore, a skull base fracture is highly unlikely in this case.

C) INCORRECT:

An epidural hematoma usually results from rupture of the middle meningeal artery due to a traumatic skull fracture. Although this patient has evidence of altered mental status (decreased feeding and arousability), and it is likely that he sustained some form of head trauma, the fundoscopic findings would be less likely to occur in patients with epidural hematoma. Furthermore, epidural hematomas are not the most common type of intracranial hemorrhage in cases of pediatric nonaccidental trauma.

D) INCORRECT:

Lobar hemorrhage is associated with cerebral amyloid angiopathy. This type of hemorrhage is typically seen in adults. This pediatric patient was most likely injured as a result of nonaccidental trauma, which does not typically cause lobar hemorrhage.

E) CORRECT:

Subdural hematomas are the most common type of intracranial hemorrhage in infants with shaken baby syndrome (SBS). In SBS, violent shaking of the baby results in whiplash and rapid rotational head movements, which lead to tearing of the intracerebral bridging veins and diffuse axonal injury. Other characteristic physical examination findings in children with SBS include irritability, lethargy, retinal hemorrhages (due to rupture of the retinal veins), and bulging fontanelles, all of which are seen here. Additional injuries that indicate child abuse include bruises to the upper torso (like the purple discoloration in the T4–T10 dermatomes seen in this patient that is most likely due to a forceful grip), posterior rib fractures, fractures at multiple stages of healing, and complex, long bone fractures (e.g., spiral humerus fractures).

Any case of suspected child abuse should be immediately reported to Child Protective Services.

Key learning point: Subdural hematoma with retinal hemorrhages and bruising in infants strongly suggests nonaccidental trauma such as shaken baby syndrome, requiring immediate evaluation for child abuse.
questions.hint: Infants do not begin to roll on their own until the age of 4–6 months. Nonaccidental trauma in children should be suspected when an inconsistent history is given by the caretaker, such as the claim that a 2-month-old infant rolled off a bed.

questions.text: A 72-year-old man presents after being found increasingly drowsy at home. His daughter reports he fell 3 weeks ago but seemed normal until 5 days ago, when he developed headaches and slowed responses. He takes warfarin for atrial fibrillation. On arrival, he is confused but follows commands, has a GCS of 14. Examination shows subtle right-sided weakness. Noncontrast head CT is shown. INR is 2.7. What is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Reverse anticoagulation and repeat CT in 24 hours
Admit for observation with neurologic checks every 4 hours
Obtain MRI to better characterize the lesion

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Reversing anticoagulation is important in all patients with intracranial bleeding, but this patient has a large, symptomatic chronic subdural hematoma with mass effect that requires more definitive intervention.

B) INCORRECT:

Observation may be appropriate for small, asymptomatic collections without midline shift. This patient has confusion, focal weakness, and significant mass effect, making observation unsafe.

C) INCORRECT:

Corticosteroids are not standard initial therapy. In a symptomatic patient with mass effect, relying on steroids delays definitive management and risks further deterioration.

D) CORRECT:

Correct -- This patient has a chronic subdural hematoma with symptomatic presentation including confusion and focal neurologic deficits. The hematoma, midline shift shown on CT, and neurologic deterioration mandate neurosurgical consultation for surgical evaluation.

E) INCORRECT:

MRI is not required for diagnosis. CT already confirms a chronic subdural hematoma with findings that dictate management. Additional imaging would only delay definitive care.

questions.text: A 2-month-old boy is brought to the emergency department by his mother because of an 8-hour history of difficulty feeding and decreased arousability. His mother says that the symptoms began after he rolled over and fell from the bed. His vital signs are within normal limits. Examination shows regions of purple discoloration in the T4–T10 dermatomes bilaterally and tense fontanelles. Fundoscopy shows bilateral optic disc swelling with dot-and-blot hemorrhages extending to the ora serrata. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Common manifestations of a basilar skull fracture include periorbital ecchymosis with CSF rhinorrhea, CSF otorrhea, mastoid ecchymosis, and otorrhagia, which are not seen in this patient. Therefore, a skull base fracture is highly unlikely in this case.

B) INCORRECT:

Lobar hemorrhage is associated with cerebral amyloid angiopathy. This type of hemorrhage is typically seen in adults. This pediatric patient was most likely injured as a result of nonaccidental trauma, which does not typically cause lobar hemorrhage.

C) INCORRECT:

An epidural hematoma usually results from rupture of the middle meningeal artery due to a traumatic skull fracture. Although this patient has evidence of altered mental status (decreased feeding and arousability), and it is likely that he sustained some form of head trauma, the fundoscopic findings would be less likely to occur in patients with epidural hematoma. Furthermore, epidural hematomas are not the most common type of intracranial hemorrhage in cases of pediatric nonaccidental trauma.

D) INCORRECT:

Bacterial meningitis is typically accompanied by altered mental status (AMS), which, in infants, can manifest subtly with symptoms ranging from irritability to lethargy. Although this patient's decreased arousability indicates acute AMS, he does not have fever or signs of meningism. This patient's presentation should raise concern for nonaccidental trauma.

E) INCORRECT:

Periventricular hemorrhage (PVH) is a major cause of neurological disabilities and most commonly occurs in preterm infants due to germinal matrix hemorrhage. However, this boy was born at full term. Furthermore, symptoms would be expected to arise within the first 1–5 days of life, not 2 months after birth. This patient was most likely injured as a result of nonaccidental trauma, which does not typically lead to PVH.

F) CORRECT:

Subdural hematomas are the most common type of intracranial hemorrhage in infants with shaken baby syndrome (SBS). In SBS, violent shaking of the baby results in whiplash and rapid rotational head movements, which lead to tearing of the intracerebral bridging veins and diffuse axonal injury. Other characteristic physical examination findings in children with SBS include irritability, lethargy, retinal hemorrhages (due to rupture of the retinal veins), and bulging fontanelles, all of which are seen here. Additional injuries that indicate child abuse include bruises to the upper torso (like the purple discoloration in the T4–T10 dermatomes seen in this patient that is most likely due to a forceful grip), posterior rib fractures, fractures at multiple stages of healing, and complex, long bone fractures (e.g., spiral humerus fractures).

Any case of suspected child abuse should be immediately reported to Child Protective Services.
questions.hint: Infants do not begin to roll on their own until the age of 4–6 months. Nonaccidental trauma in children should be suspected when an inconsistent history is given by the caretaker, such as the claim that a 2-month-old infant rolled off a bed.
